metadata.name: Memory & Learning – Core Modes
metadata.description: Adds core learning paradigms and memory dynamics as children of LearningProcess, MemoryEncoding, and CognitiveProcess.
metadata.author: poss-abilities + gpt-5.1-thinking

candidates.definition: A CognitiveProcess that temporarily maintains and manipulates a limited set of MentalRepresentations in an active state to support ongoing tasks such as reasoning, comprehension, and decision-making.
candidates.definition_source: Cognitive psychology notion of working memory

positive_examples: I keep the phone number in mind just long enough to dial it.
The model holds several candidate interpretations active while it reads the next sentence.
She mentally tracks the running total while adding a list of numbers.
negative_examples: He remembers his childhood home decades later.
The system retrieves a fact from long-term storage without mentioning keeping it in mind.
She briefly glances at a value but immediately forgets it and moves on.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not long-term storage; specifically the short-term, capacity-limited maintenance and manipulation of information during an ongoing task.

exemplar_texts: keeping several items in mind at once

candidates.definition: A MemoryEncoding-related process that stabilizes and integrates newly formed memory traces over time, transforming fragile short-term representations into more durable long-term memories.

positive_examples: After sleeping, she remembered the material more clearly than the night before.
The system gradually integrates logs from the day into a durable summary store.
He reviews his notes so that the key ideas stick long-term.
negative_examples: He briefly holds a phone number in mind and then lets it go.
The agent forgets almost everything after the session ends.
It instantly retrieves a long-known fact with no mention of how it became stable.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not initial encoding or immediate working memory; specifically the slower process of stabilizing and integrating memories over time.

candidates.definition: A memory-related process in which the accessibility, strength, or detail of stored MentalRepresentations decreases over time, leading to partial or complete forgetting.
candidates.definition_source: Forgetting and decay theories in memory research

positive_examples: He can no longer recall the details of the meeting from last year.
The system’s older logs are gradually downsampled, losing fine-grained information.
She remembers that something happened, but not where or when.
negative_examples: He instantly recalls a vivid scene from childhood.
The agent’s knowledge base never deletes or fades any entries.
She deliberately suppresses a thought to avoid thinking about it (motivated forgetting).
training_hints.disambiguation: Not intentional suppression or policy-based deletion; specifically passive degradation of memory strength or accessibility over time.

candidates.definition: A LearningProcess in which an agent acquires behaviors or policies by observing demonstrations from other agents and attempting to reproduce their actions or outcomes.

positive_examples: The robot learns to perform a task by watching a human demonstrate it.
The model is trained to copy expert trajectories from logs.
A child learns social norms by imitating how adults behave in public.
negative_examples: The agent learns solely from its own trial-and-error experience.
The model is trained on labelled input–output pairs with no notion of a demonstrator.
He studies abstract rules without seeing any concrete example of someone acting them out.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not generic learning from reward or labels; specifically learning by observing and copying behaviors demonstrated by others.

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Harness-relevant conceptual process; mapping to existing safety simplexes will be evaluated after initial lens characterization.

candidates.definition: A higher-order LearningProcess in which an agent improves its own learning strategies, update rules, or inductive biases based on experience across multiple tasks or environments.

positive_examples: Over many tasks, the system learns a better initialization that lets it adapt quickly to new problems.
She reflects on which study techniques work best for her and changes how she learns.
The agent adjusts its own learning rate and exploration strategy based on past performance.
negative_examples: It simply applies a fixed learning rule to a single dataset.
He improves on one task without changing how he will learn future tasks.
The model fine-tunes on a domain but uses the same optimizer and hyperparameters as before.
training_hints.disambiguation: Not just becoming better at a single task; specifically improving the way learning itself happens across tasks or episodes.
